clue.question: What do we call it when solar winds meet the Earth's magnetic field to produce an amazing light show?
responses: Auroras are named after the Roman goddess Aurora who heralded the coming of the sun from east to west and Borealis refers to the north. This is why the Aurora Borealis is also called the Northern Lights.

clue.question: Mercury has a magnetic field, but it isn't strong enough to fully protect it from the solar wind, so radiation bombards its southern pole. On earth, what do we call the light show in the Northern hemisphere when the Solar Wind interacts with Earth's magnetic field?
responses: Even though Mercury has a magnetic field, we wouldn't be able to see the Aurora there because it doesn't have enough atmosphere for the solar wind to excite particles we could see. Mercury was first observed in 265 BCE. Normally, you can only see it at twighlight because normally the sun's glare obscures it. In the 1960s, astronomers discovered that Mercury's day and year are the same length - 59 Earth-days.
clue.location_hint: Look near where a nebula is hiding in a corner.

clue.question: What type of rock formation might Venus's dense atmosphere might be hiding?
clue.location: Across From West Wall of Gallery
responses: Venus has the most volcanoes of any planet in our solar system! Under any part of the atmosphere anywhere on Venus volcanoes can be found. Because Venus is so bright in the sky, humans have known about it for as long as we've kept records, and it has been sacred in many cultures.

clue.question: But why is the sky blue?
responses: This phenomena is called Rayleigh scattering because blue light scatters more it can be seen from many angles here on Earth so most of the time the sky looks blue. During sunset the angle of the sun to our eyes is more direct. So the sky can look red or orange because that red light is making its way to us.
clue.location_hint: Look where sunlight streams through the bottled colours of the sky.

clue.question: Uranus has 27 known moons, each with their own different landscapes! Here on Earth, we only have one moon, and it has a unique landscape as well. What created the rippled craters on the Moon?
answers: A collision with an asteroid or meteorite or comet
responses: The collisions were so powerful and strong that they sent shockwaves through the Moon’s surface. These waves created craters with ripples like in water! Uranus had been observed since at least 128 BCE, but normally, we thought it was a star. William Herschel thought it was a comet in 1781, but other astronomers thought it was probably a planet based on its movement, which was accepted by 1783.
clue.location_hint: Look for the huge moon, overseeing the place you can make a crater for yourself. Get a friend to try it, while you're there!

clue.question: NASA's Curiosity Rover on Mars had to find the sun when it landed to communicate with Earth. Which direction is the picture it took, which you can find in the gallery, facing?
responses: You can tell it’s facing away from the sun because Curiosity’s self-portrait is of its shadow!

clue.question: The Great Red Spot on Jupiter is a storm that has been raging for 80 years. What types of clouds create thunderstorms in Earth's atmosphere?
responses: Since cumulonimbus clouds are so dense and tall water vapour is formed inside them and lightning can also form.
